awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebraic Geometry and Singularities in Positive and Mixed Characteristic
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic Geometry studies algebraic varieties which are geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. One of the most natural problems in this area is to understand the singularities that naturally occur when considering algebraic varieties and how these singularities influence the global geometry of algebraic varieties. In recent years there have been a number of breakthroughs, especially in the case where we consider solutions over the complex numbers. At the same time new techniques and approaches have emerged for studying solutions in positive and mixed characteristics. The primary goal of this collaborative project is to advance and unify these ideas to further understand and solve some of the most challenging programs in both local and global algebraic geometry. In addition the project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
The PIs will investigate singularities in positive and mixed characteristics by using a variety of techniques including those arising from the minimal model program, from the theory of F-singularities, and from Scholze's work on perfectoid algebras and spaces. The PIs will also organize workshops, a summer school and a conference, aimed at training young researchers in this area, disseminating recent results and facilitating further advances and breakthroughs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Both in the physical and theoretic worlds, many shapes are described as the zero set of a system of polynomial equations. Studying these shapes, called varieties, is the theme of the mathematical field of algebraic geometry.

If a point locally does not look the same as general points around it, then singularities arise. While people were originally most interested in varieties without singularities, it has become clear that if we want to have more flexibility to do operations on varieties in many geometric problems, such as taking a limit or making a surgery, singular varieties are unavoidable. So we need a good understanding of them, which makes it necessary to consider geometry of singularities. 

One novel theory on singularities, which has risen in the past a few years, is to study its stable degeneration. Evidences of the existence of such stable degenerations were originally rooted in differential geometers' works, but an algebraic geometric theory would significantly generalize the picture.

Partially supported by the grant, we (joint with Ziquan Zhuang) completed the proof of the uniqueness and existence of a stable degeneration for any singularity. Furthermore, we show once fixing some discrete invariants, those degenerations only vary in a controllable way, i.e. in finitely many families. 

This can be regarded as a local analogue of the stability theory for positively curved global varieties (i.e. Fano varieties). We also made substantial progress there.
